discussion.content: nslookup is a network administration command-line tool for querying the Domain Name System to obtain the mapping between domain name and IP address, or other DNS records.

questions.question_text: An administrator is working on an email migration project and needs to verify if the new MX records have propagated across the public DNS servers. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate software tool for the administrator to use?
A network team has reported multiple outages caused by unauthorized access to the IDF. Which of the following would BEST prevent this issue from reoccurring?

discussion.content: unauthorized access is the key word here

questions.question_text: Which of the following MUST be implemented to share metrics between routing protocols within the same router?

discussion.content: Routers acheive convergence by sharing their routing tables - the correct answer is B

Selected Answer: C
Since the question here is "Which of the following MUST be implemented to share metrics between routing protocols within the same router", focus should be placed on the words "between routing protocols" and "within the same router". 

Now, per the official CompTIA Approved Cert Guide songbook on page 220, a router "can support multiple routing protocols though the process of route redistribution." and to put a fine point on it, the words "route redistribution" are printed in italics. it goes on to say "Routes learned from OSPF on one area of the network can be injected into the routes learned from EIGRP in another area of the network."

Metrics are assigned to each of the routes learned by each individual protocol, and these metrics determine which routes take priority... - but you already knew that.

from page 220 of the official CompTIA network+ guide, a router can support multiple routing protocols though the process of route redistribution. Routes learned from OSPF on one area of the network can be injected into the routes learned from EIGRP in another area of the network.

The Answer for this is C. Here is a line from Cisco's own documentation:
"When you redistribute one protocol into another, remember that the metrics of each protocol play an important role in redistribution"
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/enhanced-interior-gateway-routing-protocol-eigrp/8606-redist.html
How do you "implement" a routing table? LOL. The question is asking what do you need to implement. You implement Route redistribution. The answer is C.

I think it's C
"It is fairly common to have multiple routing protocols running on the same router, since the routing protocols are independent; the routes learned are also independent. Route Redistribution allows routes learned via one routing protocol to be propagated by a different protocol."

C (route redistribution) is correct. Key phrase in the question "within the same router." A router doesn't need to share its routing table with itself. Route redistribution is exactly what's needed: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Route_redistribution
Guys, the answer is always in the details. Re-read the question. "WITHIN the same router", correct answer is routing table.

per professor messer, So one of the ways that you can take routes from one system and convert them so that they can be used in a different system is to use something like route redistribution. This can redistribute these routes that we’re learning about via one method and redistribute them through another method entirely. SInce they want it within the same router, we are looking at the routing table. 

https://www.professormesser.com/network-plus/n10-006/route-aggregation-and-redistribution/
redistribution uses the current routing tables same router each router has its own table

Route redistribution is the term used for translating from one routing protocol
into another. An example would be where you have an old router running
RIP but you have an EIGRP network. You can run route redistribution
on one router to translate the RIP routes into EIGRP.

comments.content: I meant "C" is the correct answer. Route redistribution: https://community.cisco.com/t5/networking-documents/route-redistribution-explained/ta-p/3154132

discussion.content: B is the correct answer. There is a Cisco KB article refferring to that. Two different protocols, same router.
I agree with Bones question stated “within SAME router” so C would be the best choice

This one is quite confusing. By "sharing", I was thinking of RIP translating its metrics to that of OSPF (and vice versa) so that routes from RIP can be advertised to OSPF (and again, vice versa). So I think the answer is C.

questions.question_text: A technician is installing new equipment in a datacenter and needs to identify the appropriate power and network connections. Which of the following should the technician use?

comments.content: A rack diagram would not be able to tell you the power and network requirements for a specific device you have purchased. That would be found in the user manual, which I would assume is defined as "work instructions".

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
A rack Diagram would probably help you more than work instructions. The keyword is "identify" making C a more effective answer.
Sounds more like rack diagrams to me

Endpoint security is the practice of securing endpoints or entry points of end-user devices such as desktops, laptops, and mobile devices from being exploited by malicious actors and campaigns. Endpoint security systems protect these endpoints on a network or in the cloud from cybersecurity threats.

Selected Answer: B
Ref: Endpoint hardening is essentially turning off and/or blocking as much as possible on the device without affecting required functions.

questions.question_text: Which of the following network security practices is focused on securing endpoints?
